report_title: Blow Molding Machinery Manufacturing Industry Report
executive_summary: The Blow Molding Machinery Manufacturing industry produces equipment used to make hollow plastic products, including plastic bottles and automotive parts. Private investment in industrial equipment and machinery and downstream demand are key drivers of industry performance, both of which have performed well over the five years to 2021 due to improving economic conditions. Industry growth has stemmed from a rise in investment in industrial equipment and machinery, as downstream users are expanding capacity. However, volatile steel prices led to operators slashing top-line selling prices toward the end of the period. At the same time, due to spread of COVID-19 (coronavirus) demand from downstream markets declined which negatively affected industry revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Growth paused momentarily in 2015 with industry revenue falling 6.4%, as recent gains were consolidated.

However, the industry bounced back in 2018, with growth of 4.2%. The industry grew due to an increase in private investment in industrial equipment and a steady increase in demand from the plastic bottle manufacturing industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Export revenue boosted by trade-weighted index decline
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In the second half of the period, a decrease in trade-weighted index (TWI) boosted export revenue, and this trend is expected to remain steady.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Selling prices decreased due to volatile input costs
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: However, volatility in input costs, especially steel prices, has led to top-line selling prices decreasing during the second half of the five-year period.

With the increase in the spread of COVID-19 (coronavirus), trade has been affected, making acquiring raw materials more expensive and lowering demand from downstream markets. At the same time, private investment in industrial equipment and machinery is expected to decrease due to the virus.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Blow Molding Machinery Manufacturing industry is expected to experience growth over the five years to 2026. Headwinds for industry operators include competition from foreign manufacturers, a volatile US dollar and consumer trends away from plastic products. Nevertheless, continued growth in private investment in machinery, technological advances and solid demand from downstream markets will drive industry revenue to increase at an annualized rate of 3.5% to $375.8 million over the five years to 2026.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Demand from downstream markets to rebound
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry's major customer base includes plastic bottle manufacturers, automotive part manufacturers and plastic packaging manufacturers. These three markets all rely on a healthy economy, specifically strong consumer spending, to drive demand. As the economy recovers from the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic in 2020, demand from downstream markets is expected rebound in this period.

To be closer to downstream markets, blow molding machinery manufacturers will continue to expand overseas. For example, in 2014, Milacron Holdings Corp. (Milacron) announced plans to expand production in China and India. By expanding in areas near downstream users, Milacron is able to take advantage of lower labor and transportation costs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Foreign competition to remain a threat
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Foreign competition will continue to be the industry's largest threat. For example, Taiwan has been increasingly expanding its broader plastic machinery manufacturing sector, which is currently worth more than $2.5 billion, according to the Taiwan Association of Machinery Industry. Taiwan's plastic machinery manufacturing sector is largely export-oriented, with more than 83.0% of plastic machinery leaving the country.

As a result of these trends, coupled with a rising US dollar, IBISWorld expects industry exports to rise at an annualized rate of 3.7% to $43.7 million over the next five years. Due to trade-weighted index's expected decline over the next five years, value of imports is expected to decline. Over the five years to 2026, IBISWorld expects imports to decrease at an annualized rate of 7.2% to $270.1 million.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures blow molding machinery. Blow molding is a process by which hollow plastic parts are formed.

mixed_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: medium - increasing

threats: Price of plastic materials and resin

key_trends: Volatile oil prices have negatively affected pricing conditions for industry products
With emerging market growth outpacing US GDP growth, large manufacturers are continually expanding operations near downstream users
Lower labor costs and looser regulations have made import competition extremely high
Recovery in the plastic bottle production industry will drive growth
Foreign competition will continue to be the industry's largest threat
Operators are expected to introduce machines that are more affordable to run and take up less space
The industry will continue to endure headwinds from high import penetration

market_segmentation.segment_description: The largest packaging industry is the Plastic Bottle Manufacturing industry which manufactures bottles from plastic compounds for beverage, food and chemical packaging.
The Automobile Engine and Parts Manufacturing industry uses blow molding machines to manufacture automotive parts like hoses and fuel tanks.
This segment consists of various other hollowed out products like toys and furniture parts.
The industry exports customized equipment to regions worldwide, though exports represent a declining share of revenue as domestic producers expand overseas production.

products_and_services.product_description: Extrusion blow molding machinery produces dairy containers, shampoo bottles, hoses and pipes and hollow industrial parts (e.g. drums).
Injection blow molding machines are used to produce very small containers such as pharmaceutical and hotel toiletry containers.
Stretch blow molding machinery molds plastic into a preform using the injection molding process and is used primarily for bottle and jar production.

tier_1_suppliers: Plastic & Resin Manufacturing in the US ([/ibisworld/reportkey/1/473])
Iron & Steel Manufacturing in the US ([/ibisworld/reportkey/1/569])
tier_2_suppliers: Coal & Natural Gas Power in the US ([/ibisworld/reportkey/1/1910])

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for blow molding machinery is connected to the level of activity in the manufacturing sector, which in turn, is a function of downstream demand.
Demand for industry machines are also affected by consumer attitudes toward downstream users' products like plastic bottles and packaging.
Demand for industry products depends on the price of inputs like steel and plastic/resin. Higher input prices increase operating costs and selling prices, hindering demand.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The industry generates a fair amount of revenue from exports which account for 11.5% of revenue, decreasing from 12.4% in 2016 as domestic manufacturers relocate/expand overseas production.
The industry competes heavily with imports which regularly account for close to half of domestic demand due to cost advantages of foreign manufacturers.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region accounts for the largest share of establishments at 29.9% due to its large manufacturing base, proximity to the automotive industry, and skilled workforce.
The Southeast accounts for 20.2% of establishments and 25.8% of the population. Its dense population, oil supply for plastics/resins, and proximity to markets make it an attractive location.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Industry operators must comply with federal, state and local emissions legislation, including the Clean Air Act and the Clean Water Act. While blow molding manufacturing equipment makers design their equipment and their manufacturing processes to comply with these standards, the regulations have nonetheless increased the price of the equipment and the cost of production.
The industry is subject to quality certification requirements. The American National Standards Institute is a non-profit organization that oversees quality standards for industry products.

Blow molding machinery manufacturers are bound to the Department of Labor's Occupational Safety and Health Administration regulations as set out in Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, in addition to comparable state statutes that regulate the protection of the health and safety of workers.

In response to the COVID-19 outbreak, federal, state and local policymakers have imposed regulations on many public and business activities that have contributed to the recession and required machinery producers to scale back or modify business practices.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Potential operators must be able to competitively price products, which typically requires larger-scale production facilities that allow operators to achieve economies of scale. Given the homogeneity of many industry products, price is a key differentiating factor. However, achieving economies of scale requires significant capital outlay.

The distribution and network relationships established by existing major players are additional barriers to entry for potential operators. These larger businesses have established relationships with major wholesalers, distributors, suppliers and customers. Thus, they are able to produce and distribute goods at lower costs than new entrants.
Establishing a brand name also presents a barrier for some new entrants.

basis_points.basis_description: Given the homogeneity of many products, operators primarily compete on price, quality and service. During the recession, price became an increasingly important factor in buying blow molding machinery.
The industry endures competition from imports, primarily from Asia and Europe.
The industry further encounters external competition from resellers and repairers of blow molding machinery with qualified technical, service and parts staff.
The industry also often competes with manufacturers of similar products composed of substitute materials, such as rubber, wood and tile.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Milacron Inc. is the only industry company that generates a significant portion of industry revenue, at slightly over a quarter of total revenue.
Over the five years to 2021, concentration has remained steady, after a period of increasing concentration in which many establishments were forced to exit the industry.
Over the past five years, the number of industry establishments has decreased at an estimated annualized rate of 2.1% to nine locations.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit, measured as earnings before interest and tax, for the average industry participant is expected to be 7.0% of revenue in 2021. During this period, profit has stagnated despite rising demand.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages as key input due to low automation
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Automation in this industry is relatively low, as a result, employees represent a key input in the manufacturing of blow molding machines. Wages are expected to account for 22.9% of total industry revenue in 2021.
Purchases are expected to account for an estimated 46.0% of revenue in 2021. This category makes up the largest component of the industry's cost structure.
Depreciation costs are expected to account for 1.8% of total industry revenue. Depreciation as a percent of revenue has increased over time as revenue growth has not outpaced capital expenditure.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Low marketing expenses typical for manufacturing
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Marketing expenses, which are typically low in manufacturing industries, average 0.5% of revenue in 2021.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Rent for manufacturing space and workspaces
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Manufacturing requires large plants and warehouses; these locations are often leased rather than owned. Rent accounts for 1.1% of industry revenue in 2021.
Manufacturers typically require high and steady levels of energy for the heavy machinery. Utility costs in the industry include electricity, water, gas, fuels, and other similar commodities.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Other costs include overhead and R&D
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other costs are anticipated to account for 20.2% of revenue in 2021. This segment includes overhead expenses, insurance, legal fees, logistics, administrative costs and research and development.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low capital investment per labor dollar
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: In 2021, IBISWorld estimates that the average operator will spend $0.08 in capital investment for every $1.00 spent on labor.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Wage costs higher than capital costs
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Over the past five years, wage costs have accounted for almost one-quarter of the industry's revenue. Meanwhile, capital costs (as measured by depreciation) have consistently accounted for 1.8% of total revenue.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Manual labor required for complex products
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Unlike most manufacturing industries, the Blow Molding Machinery Manufacturing industry requires manual labor to produce its products. The complex, highly technical nature of the product requires humans to be present and active during the manufacturing process.

volatility_points.volatility_description: During the first-half of the five-year period through 2021, the industry grew as a result of rebounding demand in downstream industries and strong growth in private investment in industrial equipment and machinery.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Slower growth after initial demand surge
volatility_points.volatility_description: The latter half of the period has been characterized by slower growth as downstream users purchased the bulk of their machinery at the start of the five-year period.
Blow molding machines are fairly durable and can be used for several decades. As a result, strong growth in the first-half of the period satisfied much of the pent-up demand for new equipment.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Machine technology has improved over the past five years. For example, the production capacity of extruders has been boosted by the creation of high-output twin screw extruders, improved die and calibrator designs, water tanks with greater cooling capacity, pullers with greater pulling force, and faster, more accurate saws and cutters.
Technological developments in the form of IT have benefited the industry. For example, software exists that allows companies to simulate blow molding processes.
Over the past five years, customers have expressed interest in more environmentally friendly machinery, which has resulted in some operators redesigning their products.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Import penetration has increased steadily over the past five years and continues to satisfy a large share of domestic demand in the industry.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries like China and Mexico impacted your operations?
FAQs.answer: Major company in the industry has operations abroad but a large product line demand is satisfied by low cost operators abroad.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Volatility in input prices has led to top-line selling prices decreasing over the past five years.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: Majority of operators in the industry manufacture only a few products and cater to regional markets thereby overseas expansion is not feasible.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Wage costs have remained steady on account of the nature of the manufacturing process.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in technology like 3D printing to establish a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Technological innovation has remained steady in the industry over the past five years.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Regulation has remained steady in the industry over the past five years.

FAQs.question: How have international tariffs impacted your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Majority of industry products are not affected by recent tariffs.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profitability has decreased overall as volatile input prices have increased costs for operators in the industry.

FAQs.question: How often does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Capital expenditure is a constant outflow for both small and large operators in the industry.

FAQs.question: How do you attract qualified staff? How do you train employees to reach the skill level required for your company?
FAQs.answer: Operators need to develop machinery that meets critical performance standards, including strength, durability and temperature tolerance. This requires a relatively high degree of employee skill.

FAQs.question: Do you have a reputation for good quality service? How do you create a loyal customer base?
FAQs.answer: Having a strong brand name is critical for creating recognition among consumers. In addition, fostering brand loyalty and an association with quality can mitigate some of the purely cost-based competition.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? What new technologies have you implemented in your company?
FAQs.answer: Operators must be able to take advantage of new production and product technologies as they become available.

FAQs.question: Do you keep track of changes in the world price of steel? How do you adapt to volatile fluctuations in the steel prices?
FAQs.answer: Steel forms a major input into the production of machinery for plastics industries. Steel prices have finally fallen as high demand from emerging economies began to wane, driving down the cost of this key input for domestic manufacturers.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the trade-weighted index? How is your company affected when the trade-weighted index increases versus when it decreases?
FAQs.answer: Since exports form a major component of industry revenue, exchange rates are key to understanding revenue movements. Depreciation of the US dollar makes US machinery cheaper on the world market.
